citations.narrative:
The facility does not currently maintain records of information required by this section pertaining to the acquisition or
disposition of any birds used for regulated activity. These records are needed to facilitate the tracking of, as well as
assure the legal acquisition, disposition, proper care, and handling of, such animals. The facility must make, keep, and
maintain records which fully and correctly disclose the required information pertaining to the acquisition and disposition of
birds used for regulated activity.
Correct by August 20, 2024.

A chicken was fed to the facility's bobcat as a bobcat enrichment activity approximately 1 month prior to inspection.
Whereas 4 chickens were reported at the previous inspection, only 3 were present at the current inspection. The licensee
disclosed the feeding when the inspector enquired about the status of the 4th chicken. The feeding of live animals as prey
causes unnecessary and severe harm and stress to the bird and may further risk injury to the predator. Animals must be
handled in a manner that does not cause trauma, physical harm, or excessive discomfort.
Correct by August 6, 2024.

General housekeeping around the facility needs to be addressed. There is an excess of clutter, cobweb, and dust
accumulation throughout the feed and material storage areas on the premises. Premises must be kept clean to minimize
risks to animals and facilitate proper husbandry.
Correct by August 20, 2024.

A wasp nest has developed in the bobcat enclosure, encompassing a section of fencing and support beams at the top
face of the enclosure. Insect pests such as wasps may pose an injury and medical risk to animals contained within the
enclosure. The facility must establish and maintain a safe and effective program for the control of insect pests.
Correct by August 20, 2024.

The watering bowl provided to a Red Tailed Hawk contains an accumulation of debris and algae, causing the water to
have a green hue. Unclean and unsanitary receptacles may harbor pathogens and compromise the health and well-being
of the bird. Water receptacles must be cleaned and sanitized in accordance with Section 3.158 as often as necessary to
keep them clean and free of contamination.
Correct by August 9, 2024.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
A small animal kennel provided in the American Crow enclosure is covered with excreta. Inadequate removal of excreta in
primary enclosures may expose animals to disease hazards, pests, and odors. The facility must remove excreta and other
waste from primary enclosures as often as necessary to prevent excessive accumulation and consequent risks.
Correct by August 13, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.75(b)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The facility does not currently maintain records of information required by this section pertaining to the acquisition or 
disposition of any birds used for regulated activity. These records are needed to facilitate the tracking of, as well as 
assure the legal acquisition, disposition, proper care, and handling of, such animals. The facility must make, keep, and 
maintain records which fully and correctly disclose the required information pertaining to the acquisition and disposition of 
birds used for regulated activity.  
 
Correct by August 20, 2024. 
2.131(b)(1)  Critical
   
Handling of animals. 
A chicken was fed to the facility's bobcat as a bobcat enrichment activity approximately 1 month prior to inspection. 
Whereas 4 chickens were reported at the previous inspection, only 3 were present at the current inspection. The licensee 
disclosed the feeding when the inspector enquired about the status of the 4th chicken. The feeding of live animals as prey 
causes unnecessary and severe harm and stress to the bird and may further risk injury to the predator. Animals must be 
handled in a manner that does not cause trauma, physical harm, or excessive discomfort.  
 
Correct by August 6, 2024. 
3.131(c) 
   
Sanitation. 
General housekeeping around the facility needs to be addressed. There is an excess of clutter, cobweb, and dust 
accumulation throughout the feed and material storage areas on the premises. Premises must be kept clean to minimize 
risks to animals and facilitate proper husbandry.  
 
Correct by August 20, 2024. 
3.131(d)

Sanitation. 
A wasp nest has developed in the bobcat enclosure, encompassing a section of fencing and support beams at the top 
face of the enclosure. Insect pests such as wasps may pose an injury and medical risk to animals contained within the 
enclosure. The facility must establish and maintain a safe and effective program for the control of insect pests.  
 
Correct by August 20, 2024. 
3.156 
   
Watering 
The watering bowl provided to a Red Tailed Hawk contains an accumulation of debris and algae, causing the water to 
have a green hue. Unclean and unsanitary receptacles may harbor pathogens and compromise the health and well-being 
of the bird. Water receptacles must be cleaned and sanitized in accordance with Section 3.158 as often as necessary to 
keep them clean and free of contamination. 
 
Correct by August 9, 2024. 
3.158(a)(1) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
A small animal kennel provided in the American Crow enclosure is covered with excreta. Inadequate removal of excreta in 
primary enclosures may expose animals to disease hazards, pests, and odors. The facility must remove excreta and other 
waste from primary enclosures as often as necessary to prevent excessive accumulation and consequent risks.  
 
Correct by August 13, 2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
